In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Kingdom of Cambodia has requested technical assistance (TA) from the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to develop its capacity for urban management. The TA will support 
the  ADB’s  broader  objective  of  sustainable  poverty  reduction,  as  stated  in  the  country 
partnership strategy (CPS) for Cambodia, by promoting (i) inclusive economic growth, through 
investments in physical infrastructure, and (ii) social development and equity, through basic 
education, water supply, and sanitation services.1 Establishing urban–rural links is recognized in 
the CPS as an increasingly important challenge to address as part of Cambodia’s development 
process. Urban development, through better urban management, and other community-based 
development initiatives in the Tonle Sap provinces will be mutually reinforcing. In fact, the TA 
will  supplement  two  planned  urban  projects  in  Cambodia:  (i)  Greater  Mekong  Subregion 
Corridor Towns Development Project (for loan approval in 2012), and (ii) Integrated Urban 
Environmental Management in the Tonle Sap Basin (for loan approval in 2013). The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Recognizing the need to introduce new provincial, municipal, and district systems of 
governance, the Government of Cambodia has embarked on a wide range of subnational 
governance reforms. The two strategic goals are to (i) strengthen and expand local democracy, 
and (ii) promote local development and reduce poverty. The Organic Law, approved by the 
government  in  2008,  was  designed  to  improve  the  effectiveness  and  efficiency  of  service 
delivery by Cambodia’s subnational administration through a hierarchical structure. The law has 
a sub-decree that clearly defines province and district roles and responsibilities.3 The present 
administration has vertical and horizontal components. The vertical component is the top–down 
administrative system with the municipal council and executive board of the governor being 
accountable to the higher (i.e., provincial) authority. In the horizontal component, the executive 
board of the governor works closely with the technical line departments of the national ministries 
of various sectors, such as public works and transport, environment, land management, urban 
planning and construction, rural development, health, and education.  
 
3.  The creation of municipalities and the drafting of a national urban development strategy 
and national housing policy are major achievements. Despite efforts at the national level, the 
institutional framework and capacity for urban management remain very limited, especially at 
the provincial and local levels, where the newly established municipalities are now beginning to 
play an increasingly important role. Given the limited experience of municipalities and their 
severely limited staffing, years of support and technical assistance will be required from both 
national and provincial agencies to raise the capacity of municipalities to an acceptable level. 
Capacity  development  will  be  integrated  into  ADB-supported  investment  initiatives  and  will 
attempt  to  ensure  not  only  smooth  project  implementation  but  also  the  development  of 
sustainable institutional capacities. 
 
4.  An analysis of the constraints to growth in Cambodia, produced by the World Bank in 
February 2009, identified three key challenges to rapid growth that need to be managed: 
(i) urbanization, (ii) inequality, and (iii) environmental concerns.4 While the government’s policy,

3  Government of Cambodia. 2008. Organic Law. Phnom Penh.

2              
 
as  embodied  in  the  National  Strategic  Development  Plan,  2009,  prioritizes  economic 
development and infrastructure, no consideration is given to the special role of the urban sector. 
The  importance  of  establishing  urban–rural  links  is  recognized  through  the  government’s 
Strategic Framework on Decentralization and Deconcentration, 2005 and the Supreme National 
Economic Council’s emphasis on the development of economic clusters and corridors and on 
the need for proper urban management. The CPS also recognizes the importance of water 
supply and other municipal infrastructure and services, and, therefore, supports lending to the 
urban sector in Cambodia (footnote 1). The ADB’s Urban Sector Assessment, Strategy, and 
Road Map for Cambodia emphasizes the need for capacity development in the urban sector, 
covering sector institutions and local authorities.5  
 
5.  In recent years, the government has been working on important legislation for the urban 
sector, which covers spatial planning, urbanization, land valuation, and housing policy.6 This TA 
will  assist  the  government  in  consolidation  of  an  urban  development  code,  which  will 
supplement the Subdecree on Urbanization of the Capital City, Towns, and Urban Areas of 
2011. Output 3 of the TA is specifically oriented toward this activity.     
 
6.  ADB holds regular sector dialogues with the Agence Française de Développement, the 
Australian Agency for International Development, the Export–Import Bank of Korea, German 
development cooperation through KfW, JICA, and the World Bank. Other development partners 
(like JICA) have invested in water, urban roads, and urban transport in Phnom Penh and have 
shown interest in solid waste and wastewater treatment in other towns. Both JICA and the 
Export–Import  Bank  of  Korea  have  expressed  interest  in  taking  lead  roles  in  wastewater 
treatment in Phnom Penh. The Agence Française de Développement has contributed to urban 
planning in Phnom Penh and transport studies. 
 
7.  ADB’s recent urban infrastructure experience is limited to the highly successful Phnom 
Penh Water Supply and Drainage Project7  and the successful Provincial Towns Improvement 
Project.8 In contrast, the recent wastewater treatment plants in Siem Reap and Preah Sihanouk, 
constructed  under  the  Mekong  Tourism  Development  Project,  had  problems  in  revenue 
collection  and  sustainability. 9 Additionally,  small-scale,  community-based  solid  waste 
management projects have been implemented in Phnom Penh. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The  impact  will  be  improved  urban  infrastructure  services  for  growth  and  poverty 
reduction. The outcome will be improved urban management capacity of the national, provincial, 
and municipal governments. To make this capacity development sustainable, the Ministry of 
Land Management, Urban Planning and Construction will be selected and strengthened to carry

3 
on the task of continuous capacity development in urban areas. The TA is aligned with ADB’s 
emphasis on capacity development as expressed in the urban sector assessment, strategy, and 
road map (footnote 5) and will help to ensure aid effectiveness.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  Output  1:  Implementation  of  a  pilot  urban  management  capacity  development 
program. The pilot program will consist of a training needs assessment that will lead to the 
initial design of measures for capacity development (e.g., training, systems development, and 
human resources development). The location or target of the pilot program will be selected 
among two proposed ADB urban projects (para. 1). Development of curricula, training materials, 
and  a  training  mechanism  will  result  in  a  pilot  training  program  that  will  consist  of 
(i) management workshops, intended for managers and unit heads at provincial and local levels; 
and  (ii) short  courses,  intended  for  technical  staff.  Management  workshops  will  be  geared 
toward subjects that focus on project management skills, while the short courses will deal with 
technical issues. The capacity development  approach prioritizes process management and 
maximizes existing skills and experiences, rather than duplicating the skills training programs of 
universities and technical colleges. The TA will develop the skill sets of promising junior staff 
(those with minimum skill sets) or excluded groups (e.g., female staff), and will enhance staff 
capacities  as  part  of  the  government’s  career  development  strategy.  These  capacity 
development activities are intended to focus on land management and spatial planning, project 
preparation  and  implementation  (such  as  subproject  feasibility  studies),  procurement, 
environmental safeguards (such as climate change adaptation), resettlement, operation and 
maintenance, and project evaluation and monitoring. Preparatory work will include (i) a review of 
constraints, opportunities, and practical limitations for female staff; (ii) an analysis of existing 
staff  ratios  in  management  or  technical  position  of  local  authorities;  (iii) the  targeting  of 
participants  to  include  women  and  promising  non-managers;  and  (iv)  a  human  resource 
development plan to address challenges and limitations and to develop careers. 
 
10.  Output 2: Scaling-up of the urban management capacity development program. 
Once  the  pilot  activities  have  been  completed,  measures  for  scaling  up  the  capacity 
development program will be prepared. The municipalities that will participate in the scaling-up 
activities will be those covered by the Greater Mekong Subregion Corridor Towns Development 
Project (Poipet, Battambang, Neak Loeung, and Bavet) and the Integrated Urban Environmental 
Management in the Tonle Sap Basin (Serei Saophoan, Siem Reap, Kampong Thom, Pursat, 
and  Kampong  Chhnang)  (para. 1).  Experienced  urban  managers  from  bigger  cities  and 
provinces  will  share  their  experiences  and  practical  approaches  with  the  managers  and 
technical  staff  of  other  local  authorities.  Output  2  will  be  cosponsored  through  the  in-kind 
contributions  of  local  authorities  (provinces,  cities  or  municipalities)  and  will  include  the 
preparation of a set of consolidated training materials. The technical courses will cover the 
following subjects: (i) urban planning and land management, (ii) contract management and 
procurement, (iii) social and environmental safeguards, and (iv) operation and maintenance of 
urban infrastructure.  
 
11.  Output 3: Finalization of the urban development strategy document. The TA will 
assist the executing agency in finalizing the draft strategy document. This document will include 
a draft urban development code that will assess the gender sensitivity of urban development 
code.  The  TA  consultants  will  participate  in  government  consultation  meetings  to  receive 
feedback and guidance on the draft document.

4              
 
12.  Output  4:  Institutionalization  of  the  urban  management  capacity  development 
program. Under the TA, the executing agency and the selected national institution (Training 
Centre for Land Management under the Ministry of Land Management, Urban Planning and 
Construction) will undergo a training of trainers program. Subsequently, the executing agency 
will propose funding sources to ensure the sustainability of the program and its future activities.  
 
13.  The  consolidation  of  the  capacity  development  program  will  need  to  go  beyond 
information  exchange  for  managers  and  training  of  technical  staff  by  (i)  assessing  which 
management systems need to be introduced or enhanced; (ii) providing opportunities for more 
equitable  decision-making  processes;  and  (iii)  broadening  participation  in  organizational 
management. This could include financial management software, e-procurement, geographic 
information systems, land valuation systems, human resources development, and management 
of the existing urban information system (known as “district data books”). Further capacity 
development requirements may be related to the establishment of a subnational investment 
facility under the Decentralization and Deconcentration Three-Year Implementation Plan, 2011–
2013. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $900,000 equivalent. The Government of Cambodia has 
requested ADB to finance $700,000 equivalent, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, and communication facilities 
for consultants (Appendix 2). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The  Ministry  of  Land  Management,  Urban  Planning  and  Construction  will  be  the 
executing agency. The Training Centre for Land Management  will be the implementing agency. 
The Economic and Finance Institute under the Ministry of the Economy and Finance may be 
involved in conducting training courses that involve its area of specialization.  
 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months, from 1 October 2012 to 31 March 2014. 
The  TA  will  finance  an  estimated  7  person-months  for  an  international  consultant  and 
106 person-months for national consultants. The international and national consultants will be 
engaged through firm(s), according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The quality- and cost-based selection method, using the quality–
cost ratio of 80:20 and full technical procedures will be followed. Disbursements under the TA 
will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, 
as amended from time to time).  
 
17.  The team of consultants will operate under the guidance of a team leader, assisted by 
the international advisor (urban development and management expert). The core team will 
comprise a civil engineer, procurement specialist, social safeguards specialist, environment 
specialist, and urban planner. The urban planner will be the deputy team leader. The terms of 
reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
18.  The TA will be aligned with the government’s agenda for (i) environment and climate 
change, and (ii) decentralization and deconcentration. Expected outputs and outcomes will be 
disseminated  through  government  channels,  according  to  the  Law  on  Administrative 
Management of the Capital, Provinces, Municipalities, Districts, and Khans (footnote 3).

5 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 to the Government 
of Cambodia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for 
Capacity Development for Urban Management, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General Requirements 
 
1.  The team of consultants will consist of national specialists and an international advisor 
(urban development and management expert). The team leader will be the urban management 
and finance expert, while the deputy team leader will be the urban planner. The consultants are 
required to implement four major outputs:  
2.  Output  1:  Implementation  of  a  pilot  urban  management  capacity  development 
program. The pilot program will consist of a training needs assessment that will lead to the 
initial design of pilot capacity development measures (training, systems development, human 
resources development). Development of curricula, training materials, and a training mechanism 
will result in a pilot program, which will be tested in (i) management workshops—intended for 
managers and unit heads at provincial and local levels, and (ii) short courses—intended for 
technical staff. Management workshops will focus on “how to manage” subjects, while technical 
short courses will deal with “how to do it” issues. The capacity development approach prioritizes 
management of processes and maximization of existing skills and experiences, rather than 
duplicating the skills training programs of institutions of higher technical learning (universities 
and  technical  colleges).  Substance-wise,  these  activities  are  intended  to  focus  on  project 
preparation and implementation, e.g., subproject feasibility studies, procurement, environmental 
safeguards  (including  climate  change  adaptation),  social  safeguards,  operation  and 
maintenance, and project evaluation and monitoring. Preparatory work should include (i) a 
review of the key challenges, constraints, and opportunities for women, and (ii) a medium- to 
long-term capacity development and human resources development plan to bring women into 
decision-making  positions  in  the  urban  management  sector  in  provincial  and  municipal 
governments. 
 
3.  Output 2: Scaling-up of the urban management capacity development program. 
Once  the  pilot  activities  have  been  completed,  measures  for  scaling  up  the  capacity 
development program will be prepared. These will involve all municipalities to be covered by the 
Greater Mekong Subregion Corridor Towns Development Project and the Integrated Urban 
Environmental  Management  in  the  Tonle  Sap  Basin  Project  (both  proposed  for  ADB  loan 
approval in 2012–2013). Experienced urban managers from bigger cities and provinces will 
share their experiences and practical approaches with managers and technical staff of other 
local  authorities.  The  scaling-up  of  the  program  will  be  cosponsored  through  in-kind 
contributions of the local authorities (provinces, cities or municipalities). Output 2 will include the 
preparation of a set of consolidated training materials. The technical courses will cover the 
following subjects: (i) urban planning and land management, (ii) contract management and 
procurement, (iii) social and environmental safeguards, and (iv) operation and maintenance of 
urban infrastructure. 
 
4.  Output 3: Finalization of the urban development strategy document. The technical 
assistance (TA) will assist the executing agency in finalizing the draft strategy document, which 
will  include  an  urban  development  code.  The  consultants  will  participate  in  government 
consultation meetings to receive feedback and guidance on the draft document.
